title: Unitary representations of compact quantum groups

title_detail.value: Unitary representations of compact quantum groups

summary:
Let v be the right regular representation of a compact quantum group G. Then
(S.L.Woronowicz, "Compact quantum groups") v contains all irreducible
representations of G and each irreducible representation enters v with the
multiplicity equal to its dimension. The result is certainly known for
classical compact groups. We give a short survey on the subject and provide a
different proof of Woronowicz's result above. The proof is an adaptation of the
corresponding result for classical compact groups and provides a concrete
decomposition of the right regular representation in irreducible components.

summary_detail.value:
Let v be the right regular representation of a compact quantum group G. Then
(S.L.Woronowicz, "Compact quantum groups") v contains all irreducible
representations of G and each irreducible representation enters v with the
multiplicity equal to its dimension. The result is certainly known for
classical compact groups. We give a short survey on the subject and provide a
different proof of Woronowicz's result above. The proof is an adaptation of the
corresponding result for classical compact groups and provides a concrete
decomposition of the right regular representation in irreducible components.

author: Raluca Dumitru
fulltext:
arXiv:math/0609676v1 [math.OA] 25 Sep 2006

UNITARY REPRESENTATIONS OF
COMPACT QUANTUM GROUPS
RALUCA DUMITRU

Abstract. Let v be the right regular representation of a compact quantum
group G. Then ([6], Proposition 4.4) v contains all irreducible representations
of G and each irreducible representation enters v with the multiplicity equal
to its dimension. The result is certainly known for classical compact groups
([1]). The aim of this paper is to give a short survey on this subject and to
provide a different proof of Woronowicz's result. The proof is an adaptation of
the corresponding result for classical compact groups and provides a concrete
decomposition of the right regular representation in irreducible components.

Quantum groups have been studied in the last decades by a large number of
mathematicians and physicists. There are several approaches to the theory of quantum groups but the one used in this paper is the C*-algebraic approach introduced
by S. L. Woronowicz ([5], [6]).
Definition 1 ([6],Definition 2.1). A compact quantum group G is given by a pair
(A,∆) with A a unital C*-algebra and ∆ : A → A ⊗ A a unital ∗-homomorphism
with the following properties:
(1) The diagram is commutative

(1 ⊗ A)∆(A) = A ⊗ A
Note that the tensor product is the minimal tensor product and that there is no
separability assumption on A as in Woronowicz's original definition ([6], Definition
2.1). The separability assumption was used by Woronowicz for proving the existence
of the Haar state. In [4] Van Daele proved that this assumption is not necessary
2000 Mathematics Subject Classification. 20G42, 46L05.
Key words and phrases. compact quantum groups, right regular representation, irreducible
representation.
1

RALUCA DUMITRU

by showing that a Haar state exists and is unique without assuming that A is
separable. The result is the following:
Proposition 2 ([6], Theorem 2.3; [4], Proposition 2.4). Let G=(A,∆) be a compact
quantum group. Then there exists a unique state h on A with the property
(id ⊗ h)∆(a) = (h ⊗ id)∆(a) = h(a) * 1A
Then h is called the Haar state on G. Note that the Haar state is not always
faithful as in the case of classical compact groups. There exists however a subset of
A, denoted by A, on which h is faithful. A is called the Woronowicz-Hopf ∗-algebra
and is defined in terms of irreducible unitary representations of G. Applying the
GNS construction to h we obtain a Hilbert space Hh , a representation πh of A and
a cyclic vector ξh . If a ∈ A (or a ∈ A) and f is a bounded linear functional (on A
or A), we denote ([5], [6])
a ∗ f = (f ⊗ ι)(∆(a))
f ∗ a = (ι ⊗ f )(∆(a))
Both a ∗ f and f ∗ a are elements of A (respectively A).
Let H be a Hilbert space and denote by K(H) the set of compact operators on
H. A unitary representation u of G acting on a Hilbert space H is a unitary element
in the multiplier algebra M(K(H) ⊗ A) with the property (id ⊗ ∆)u = u12 u13 . The
leg numbering notation used (u12 , u13 ) is the one obtained from the two possible
inclusions of K(H) ⊗ A in K(H) ⊗ A ⊗ A. The representation u is called irreducible
if the operators intertwining u (i.e. S ∈ B(Hu ) such that (S ⊗ 1)u = u(S ⊗ 1),
where Hu denotes the Hilbert space on which u acts) are scalar multiples of the
identity. If u is irreducible then it is finite dimensional (i.e. dimHu < ∞) and
if we denote by d = dimHu then d is called the dimension of u. By choosing an
orthonormal basis in Hu , the Hilbert space of an irreducible representation u, we
can identify u with a matrix (uij )16i,j6d over A.
Two unitary representations u and v are called equivalent (denoted by u ∼ v)
if and only if there exists U : Hu → Hv unitary such that (U ⊗ 1)u = v(U ⊗ 1). Let
b denote the dual of G, i.e. the set of all unitary equivalence classes of irreducible

Among the unitary representations of G a special role is played by the right
regular representation, defined by S. L. Woronowicz as follows:
Theorem 4 ([6], Theorem 5.1). With the notation introduced above
(1) There exists unique v ∈ M(K(H) ⊗ A) such that
[(id ⊗ f )v]πh (a)ξh = πh (f ∗ a)ξh
for any f continuous linear functional on A, any a ∈ A.
(2) v is a unitary representation of G.

 4

RALUCA DUMITRU

(3) The set
{(ρ ⊗ id)v | ρ continuous linear f unctional on K(Hh )}
is dense in A.
Then v is called the right regular representation of the compact quantum group
G. The set of intertwiners of v and the definition of C ∗ (G) are given in the following
theorem:
Theorem 5 ([6], Theorem 4.1). Let v be the right regular representation of a
compact quantum group G = (A, ∆). Let C ∗ (G) be the norm closure of the set of
all operators of the form
Fv (a) = (id ⊗ ha)(v ∗ ),
where a ∈ A. Then
(1) v ∈ M(C ∗ (G) ⊗ A)
(2) An operator X ∈ B(Hh ) intertwines v with itself (i.e. (X ⊗ id)v = v(X ⊗
id)) if and only if X commutes with all elements of C ∗ (G).
Consider now V ∈ B(Hh ⊗ Hh ) defined by V = (id ⊗ πh )v. The following result
is implicitly contained in ([5], [6]):
Lemma 6. V (πh (a)ξh ⊗ ξ) = (πh ⊗ πh )(∆(a))(ξh ⊗ ξ), ∀a ∈ A, ∀ξ ∈ Hh .
With Hh (uα ) introduced above, the orthogonal projection onto this subspace of
Hh is pα = Fv (aα ). Using the multiplication in C ∗ (G) as described in ([6], formula
4.4) one can show that pα is a central projection in C ∗ (G). By equation 1 above,

 UNITARY REPRESENTATIONS

5

Remark 8. Since the unit pα of B(Hh (uα )) belongs to C ∗ (G)pα , then C ∗ (G)pα
is a subfactor of B(Hh (uα )). Using ([2], page 118) B(Hh (uα )) is isomorphic to
C ∗ (G)pα ⊗ (C ∗ (G)pα )′ and, by reasons of dimension, (C ∗ (G)pα )′ is isomorphic to
the full matrix algebra Mdα ×dα .
The description of the right regular representation is given by S. L. Woronowicz ([6], Proposition 5.4). He proved that every irreducible representation enters
the right regular representation with the multiplicity equal to its dimension. The
result is certainly known for classical compact groups (see for instance [1], Section
27.49). A. Maes and A. Van Daele ([3], Theorem 6.7) gave a simpler proof to the
fact that every irreducible representation is contained in the right regular representation. The aim of this paper is to give a proof of Woronowicz's result, including
the multiplicities, which is an adaptation of the corresponding result for classical
compact groups and is different from both Woronowicz's and Maes and Van Daele's
proofs. The proof we give is based on the structure of C ∗ (G) and its commutant and
provides a concrete decomposition of the right regular representation in irreducible
components.
Proposition 9 ([6], Proposition 5.4). The right regular representation v contains
all irreducible representations of G. Each irreducible
enters v with

therefore equivalent to uα . This restriction is given by v(pkα ⊗ 1).

References
[1] E. Hewitt, K. A. Ross, Abstract harmonic analysis, Vol. II, Springer-Verlag, Berlin-HeidelbergNew York, 1970.
[2] N. Jacobson, Structure of rings, Amer. Math. Soc. Colloquium Publications, Vol. 37, Providence, Rhode Island, 1956.
[3] A. Maes, A. Van Daele, Notes on Compact Quantum Groups, Nieuw Archief voor Wiskunde
16 (1998), 73-112.
[4] A. Van Daele, The Haar Measure on a Compact Quantum Group, Proceedings of the American
Mathematical Society, Vol. 123, No. 10 (1995) , pp. 3125-3128.
[5] S. L. Woronowicz, Compact matrix pseudogroups, Comm. Math. Phys. 111 (1987), no. 4,
613-665.
[6] S. L. Woronowicz, Compact quantum groups, Quantum Symmetries, Proceedings of the Les
Houches summer school (1995), North Holland, Amsterdam (1998), 845-884.
